definition: you win some, you lose some (idiom)/gains and losses/trade-off
to have/there is/there are/to exist/to be
structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc
to have to/must/ought to/to need to
to obtain/to get/to gain/to catch (a disease)/proper/suitable/proud/contented/to allow/to permit/ready/finished
to have/there is/there are/to exist/to be

sentences.english: Under the influence of the school of mind, he was both successful and unsuccessful.
sentences.chinese: 在陽明心學思想影響下，他有得有失。

sentences.english: Anyway, I'll make all my effort on it!
sentences.chinese: 有得有失，我知道努力是不被會白費的。

sentences.english: The present Chinese TV mode has both advantages and disadvantages.
sentences.chinese: 現階段中國電視模式引進有得有失。

sentences.english: Have gain have loss, that's is life.
sentences.chinese: 有得有失，生活就是如此。

sentences.english: It's been a day of gains and losses for the military in Iraq.
sentences.chinese: 對駐伊美軍來說，這是有得有失的一天。

sentences.english: These revisions which have changed the nature of the text, have both merits and demerits.
sentences.chinese: 這些修改改變了文本本性，在藝術上有得有失。

sentences.english: There are trade-offs to being an expat.
sentences.chinese: 旅居國外也是有得有失。
